elements.title: Solitude-Companionship Rhythm Strip: Temporal Information Architecture for the Host's Week
elements.problem: The host's primary information need during active lease is not what happened (past stays) or what is owed (payments) but what is coming: when is the guest here, when am I alone, when does my week shift between shared space and private space? Csikszentmihalyi establishes that 'keeping order in the mind from within is very difficult. We need external goals, external stimulation, external feedback to keep attention directed' (lines 199-201). The host's Stays Manager currently provides administrative information (dates, payments, messages) but not the temporal rhythm information that structures their lived experience. Without a scannable weekly rhythm, the host's attention wanders into speculation: 'Is the guest arriving tonight? Will I have the kitchen to myself tomorrow morning?' This is the psychic entropy Csikszentmihalyi warns about -- 'worries are always hovering at the periphery of attention' (lines 210-212). The user stories confirm that 'urgency should surface first on the dashboard,' but urgency (what needs action now) is only half the temporal picture. Rhythm (what my week looks like) is the other half -- and it is the half that directly shapes the host's daily quality of life.
elements.solution: Design a weekly rhythm strip as the Stays Manager's primary visual information element. The strip displays 7 days in a horizontal row, with each day showing one of three states: guest-present (filled, indicating shared space), guest-absent (open, indicating solitude), and transition (half-filled, indicating arrival or departure day). Below each day, a single line of contextual text: 'Guest arrives 3pm' or 'Space is yours.' Above the strip, the current day is highlighted with a subtle marker. The rhythm strip is always visible at the top of the Stays Manager without scrolling. It answers the host's primary question -- 'What does my week look like?' -- in under 3 seconds. When a date change request is pending, the affected days pulse gently to signal that the rhythm may shift, and tapping them shows the proposed change alongside the current schedule. The strip evolves across the lease: early weeks show the first few stay cycles as the host learns the rhythm; mid-lease shows the established pattern with variation markers; late-lease shows the winding-down period with lease-end clearly visible.

evidence.quote: Keeping order in the mind from within is very difficult. We need external goals, external stimulation, external feedback to keep attention directed.
evidence.insight: The rhythm strip IS the external structure that keeps the host's attention directed. Without it, they must construct their weekly schedule mentally from raw date data -- a cognitive load that produces the psychic entropy Csikszentmihalyi describes.

evidence.source: user-stories-initial-analysis.md, 'Urgency should surface first on the dashboard'
evidence.quote: Unread proposals, pending actions, incomplete listings -- that's what a host needs to see the moment they log in. Everything else is secondary to what's waiting for them right now.
evidence.insight: The rhythm strip complements urgency surfacing: urgency shows what needs action NOW; the rhythm strip shows what the week LOOKS LIKE. Together they answer both 'What do I need to do?' and 'When am I sharing my space?' -- the two questions that structure the host's active-lease consciousness.

evidence.quote: Dorothy has strict routines for every day of the year: up by five, check the hens for eggs, milk the goat, split some wood, make breakfast, wash, sew, fish, and so on.
evidence.insight: Dorothy's routines prevent entropy by structuring time. The rhythm strip is the host's Dorothy routine -- a visible temporal structure that makes each day's social state predictable and manageable.

evidence.quote: The ultimate test for the ability to control the quality of experience is what a person does in solitude, with no external demands to give structure to attention.
evidence.insight: The host's open days (guest absent) are their solitude periods. Knowing in advance when these occur allows the host to plan productive solo activities -- the 'taming solitude' that Csikszentmihalyi identifies as essential for well-being.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: this week's rhythm (7-day strip with guest-present/absent states). Secondary: today's specific status (arrival time, departure confirmation, or solitude). Tertiary: next week's rhythm preview (collapsed, expandable). The host scans rhythm first, focuses on today second, and plans ahead third.
elements.disclosure_pattern: The rhythm strip is always fully visible -- no progressive disclosure needed because the information is inherently scannable (7 simple states). Contextual detail (arrival times, date change proposals) appears on tap/hover for individual days. Next week's preview appears below the current week when the host scrolls or explicitly expands. Historical weeks are accessible but not surfaced -- the host lives in the present and near-future.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 3 visual states per day cell (present, absent, transition). Maximum 1 line of contextual text per day. No more than 7 days visible simultaneously. The entire strip must be parseable in a single glance -- under 3 seconds. Date change proposals are indicated by a subtle visual overlay on affected days, not by additional data points.
scan_order: today's status (highlighted day in the strip)
this week's overall rhythm (scanning the 7-day pattern)
transition days (arrival/departure, if any)
date change indicators (if any pending requests)
exclude: payment information in the rhythm strip (belongs in a separate section)
historical stay data in the primary view (accessible elsewhere)
guest personal details (the strip shows presence/absence, not who)
multi-week calendar views that overwhelm the immediate temporal picture

elements.title: Differentiation Feedback in the Listing Wizard: Calibration, Not Competition
elements.problem: The listing wizard provides completion feedback (percentage of fields filled) but not differentiation feedback (how well the listing expresses the host's unique offer). Csikszentmihalyi describes differentiation as 'each person is encouraged to develop his or her unique traits' (lines 668-669), and Dorothy's personalization of her surroundings (lines 386-394) illustrates what genuine self-expression looks like. But a host filling out the wizard has no information about whether their listing will stand out or blend in. They do not know what guests look for, what other hosts in their area emphasize, or whether their house rules are standard or distinctive. The completion percentage is a flow-feedback mechanism (lines from user stories: 'a visible progress indicator creates just enough friction to get them to finish'), but it measures effort, not quality. A host who completes 100% of fields with generic answers receives the same completion signal as a host who writes distinctive, personality-rich descriptions. The information architecture fails to guide differentiation because it provides quantity feedback without quality calibration.
elements.solution: Add a differentiation calibration layer to the listing wizard that shows the host how their choices compare to the local market -- not competitively, but informationally. After each wizard step, surface 1-2 brief calibration signals. Step 1 (Space Snapshot): 'Most listings in your area include kitchen access -- you have not mentioned it. Want to add it?' Step 5 (House Rules): 'You selected 3 standard rules. Hosts in Williamsburg who add personalized rules (like quiet hours or shared-space schedules) receive 15% more proposals.' Step 6 (Photos): 'Listings with 5+ photos showing both rooms and common spaces get 25% more engagement.' These calibration signals are informational, not evaluative. They help the host understand the information landscape guests use to differentiate between listings. The signals appear as collapsible hints below each step's completion confirmation -- visible for hosts who want guidance, dismissible for those who do not. Pricing calibration follows the same pattern: the default price is shown alongside the local range ('$850/night -- similar listings range from $750-$1,050'), giving the host the context to evaluate whether the default serves their goals.

evidence.quote: Differentiation means that each person is encouraged to develop his or her unique traits, maximize personal skills, set individual goals.
evidence.insight: Calibration signals encourage differentiation by showing the host what is standard (so they can choose to diverge) and what is absent (so they can fill gaps). The host develops unique traits not by following a template but by understanding the baseline and choosing where to add their personality.

evidence.source: user-stories-initial-analysis.md, 'Completion percentage is a good host nudge'
evidence.quote: Hosts need to know what's unfinished before a listing goes live. A visible progress indicator on the listing card creates just enough friction to get them to finish -- without being in the way.
evidence.insight: Completion percentage is a quantitative feedback mechanism. Differentiation calibration is a qualitative feedback mechanism. Together they answer 'How much have I done?' (completion) and 'How well am I doing it?' (calibration) -- both necessary for the flow conditions Csikszentmihalyi describes.

evidence.quote: As extensions of Dorothy's taste, this 'junk' creates a familiar environment where her mind can be at ease. In the midst of untamed nature, she has introduced her own idiosyncratic style, her own civilization.
evidence.insight: Calibration signals help the host recognize their 'own civilization' and express it. A host who sees that most local listings do NOT mention quiet mornings may realize this is a differentiating feature of their space worth highlighting.

evidence.quote: Cicero once wrote that to be completely free one must become a slave to a set of laws. In other words, accepting limitations is liberating.
evidence.insight: Pricing calibration (showing the local range) provides the 'laws' within which the host can freely set their price. Without the range, the host faces an unconstrained decision that produces paralysis. With it, they accept a constraint that liberates: 'I will price within the range based on what my space offers.'

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: completion percentage (how much is done -- quantitative, always visible). Secondary: differentiation calibration signals (how well it is done -- qualitative, collapsible hints). Tertiary: market context for pricing (how it compares -- visible during pricing step only). The host sees progress first, quality guidance second, and market positioning third.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Completion percentage is persistent -- visible on every wizard step and on the listing card. Differentiation calibration signals appear after each step's primary fields are completed, as a collapsible section below the step summary. The host can expand them to see guidance or skip them entirely. Pricing calibration appears inline within the pricing step, adjacent to the default value. All calibration signals are dismissible and do not block progression -- a host who ignores them still completes the wizard normally.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 2 calibration signals per wizard step. Each signal is 1 sentence plus 1 data point. No signal requires the host to navigate away from the current step. The total additional cognitive load of all calibration signals across the full wizard is under 3 minutes of reading time -- optional, not required.
scan_order: completion percentage (persistent, top of each step)
step-specific form fields (primary task)
calibration signal (below fields, after completion)
pricing range context (inline with price field)
exclude: competitive rankings ('Your listing is #7 in your area')
evaluative judgments ('Your listing needs improvement')
mandatory calibration reviews that block progression
calibration data from dissimilar markets (show only the host's neighborhood/area)

elements.title: Reciprocal Feedback Loop: Per-Stay Review Information Architecture
elements.problem: Csikszentmihalyi identifies 'clear feedback' and 'open channels of communication' as essential for maintaining flow in family relationships: 'If a husband does not know what bothers his wife, and vice versa, neither has the opportunity to reduce the inevitable tensions that will arise' (lines 694-696). Per-stay reviews are the mechanism for this reciprocal feedback in the host-guest relationship, but the information architecture around them is missing. The host does not know whether the guest found the space clean, whether the house rules were clear, or whether the stay met expectations -- unless a formal review is submitted. And reviews typically happen at lease end, when the feedback is retrospective rather than actionable. Csikszentmihalyi's family flow requires ongoing feedback, not post-mortem assessment: 'without concentration, a complex activity breaks down into chaos' (line 870). A 13-week lease with feedback only at week 13 means 12 weeks of unmonitored cohabitation where small irritations can compound into relationship-breaking conflicts. The user stories' cross-activation principle applies: 'Every review is a past guest activating a future one.' But per-stay micro-reviews also serve as mid-lease communication -- each one tells the host how the current relationship is going, not just how it went.
elements.solution: Design a per-stay micro-review information architecture that makes reciprocal feedback lightweight, regular, and actionable. After each stay cycle (guest departs and sends cleaning photos), both host and guest receive a brief feedback prompt. The host's prompt: 'How was this stay?' with a 5-point scale and an optional one-sentence note. The guest's prompt: the same. Both responses are shared with the other party after both have submitted (preventing influence bias). The information architecture surfaces this feedback in three locations: (1) The rhythm strip: completed stay-cycle segments on the rhythm strip show a small indicator if a review was submitted (green dot) or is pending (amber dot). The host can tap a completed segment to see the guest's review for that stay. (2) The Stays Manager body: a 'recent feedback' section shows the last 2-3 micro-reviews from the guest, so the host can track the relationship's trajectory. An upward trend in ratings signals flow; a downward trend signals entropy that needs attention. (3) The lease-end summary: all per-stay micro-reviews aggregate into a narrative timeline that shows how the cohabitation experience evolved. This is both retrospective feedback for the host and prospective trust data for future guests.

evidence.quote: As with any other flow activity, family activities should also provide clear feedback. In this case, it is simply a matter of keeping open channels of communication. If a husband does not know what bothers his wife, and vice versa, neither has the opportunity to reduce the inevitable tensions that will arise. In this context it is worth stressing that entropy is the basic condition of group life.
evidence.insight: Per-stay reviews are the 'open channels of communication' that prevent cohabitation entropy. Without them, neither host nor guest knows whether the other is satisfied, and small tensions amplify silently until the relationship breaks down.

evidence.quote: Every review is a past guest activating a future one. The trust infrastructure is cross-activation infrastructure.
evidence.insight: Per-stay micro-reviews serve double duty: they provide ongoing feedback to the current host-guest relationship (maintaining flow) AND they accumulate into the trust data that activates future guests (powering cross-activation). The information architecture must serve both purposes.

evidence.quote: To play the trumpet well, a musician cannot let more than a few days pass without practicing. An athlete who does not run regularly will soon be out of shape... Any manager knows that his company will start falling apart if his attention wanders. In each case, without concentration, a complex activity breaks down into chaos.
evidence.insight: Weekly reviews are the 'practice' that keeps the hosting relationship in shape. A host who gets feedback every week can adjust; a host who gets feedback only at lease end discovers problems too late to fix them.

evidence.quote: When a family has a common purpose and open channels of communication, when it provides gradually expanding opportunities for action in a setting of trust, then life in it becomes an enjoyable flow activity.
evidence.insight: The per-stay review system creates all three conditions: common purpose (a well-functioning stay), open communication (reciprocal feedback), and trust (each party sees the other's honest assessment). This is Csikszentmihalyi's recipe for family flow applied to the host-guest household.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: review prompt after each stay cycle (immediate, actionable). Secondary: recent feedback summary on the Stays Manager (ongoing relationship status). Tertiary: cumulative review timeline at lease end (retrospective narrative). The hierarchy follows temporal proximity: now > recent > historical.
elements.disclosure_pattern: The review prompt appears once after each stay cycle -- tapping it opens a compact form (5-point scale + optional text). It disappears once submitted and does not reappear until the next cycle ends. The recent feedback summary is always visible in the Stays Manager body but collapses if no new reviews exist since last visit. The cumulative timeline appears only in the lease-end summary view. Guest reviews are revealed to the host only after the host also submits -- preventing the host from being influenced by the guest's rating before giving their own.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: The review prompt requires exactly 1 tap (rating) and optionally 1 sentence. Maximum time to complete: 30 seconds. The recent feedback summary shows maximum 3 recent reviews without scrolling. Each review is 1 rating + 1 sentence maximum. The cumulative timeline at lease end shows all reviews but with expandable detail -- only ratings are visible by default.
scan_order: review prompt indicator on the rhythm strip (after stay cycle ends)
5-point scale (primary review action)
optional text field (secondary, expandable)
recent feedback section (guest's latest reviews, visible on Stays Manager)
exclude: complex review forms with multiple rating categories
mandatory text reviews (the one-sentence note is always optional)
guest reviews visible before host has submitted their own
aggregate scores that compare hosts to each other

elements.title: Proposal Social Profile: Guest Assessment Information at the Decision Gate
elements.problem: The host evaluating a proposal must make a high-stakes social decision -- inviting a stranger into their home -- with insufficient social information. Csikszentmihalyi warns: 'People are the most flexible, the most changeable aspect of the environment we have to deal with' (lines 119-120). The proposal contains terms (dates, price, duration) but the host's actual question is social: 'Will this person respect my space? Will they follow my rules? Will cohabitation with them be flow or entropy?' The user stories identify that 'a well-structured proposal activates the host to respond' while 'a vague one creates friction.' But even a well-structured proposal with no guest context leaves the host guessing about the person behind the dates. The host in this phase is performing what Csikszentmihalyi calls social assessment -- the same evaluation any family makes when a new person enters the household: 'genetic programming may predispose us to attachment to family members, the cultural context will have a great deal to do with the strength and direction of that attachment' (lines 521-525). The platform's 'cultural context' is the information it provides about the guest.
elements.solution: Design the proposal view with a dual-column information architecture: terms on the left, social profile on the right. The terms column shows what the guest is proposing (dates, duration, price, any personal message). The social profile column shows who is proposing: verification status (ID verified badge), platform history (number of previous stays, member-since date), reviews from previous hosts (most recent 2-3, with excerpts), response time and communication quality indicators, and proposal quality signal (completeness percentage, presence of personal message). This dual-column layout ensures the host can assess terms and person simultaneously, without navigating between screens. A proposal quality indicator (compact visual -- a completeness bar or rating) appears at the top of the proposal card, allowing the host to triage multiple proposals before diving into any one. For counter-proposals, the terms column becomes editable: changed elements are highlighted with the impact shown inline ('Changing from 16 to 10 weeks saves you 6 weeks of hosting but reduces total income by $5,100'). The information architecture frames countering as creative adjustment, not rejection.

evidence.quote: People are the most flexible, the most changeable aspect of the environment we have to deal with. The same person can make the morning wonderful and the evening miserable. Because we depend so much on the affection and approval of others, we are extremely vulnerable to how we are treated by them.
evidence.insight: The social profile column addresses this vulnerability by making the guest less of an unknown variable. Reviews from previous hosts, verification status, and communication indicators reduce the flexibility (unpredictability) of the incoming person.

evidence.quote: A well-structured proposal -- clear dates, schedule, pricing, intent -- activates the host to respond. A vague or incomplete one creates friction.
evidence.insight: The proposal quality indicator makes this assessment instant. The host sees at a glance whether the guest invested psychic energy in a structured, thoughtful proposal -- which is a proxy for how much psychic energy they will invest in the cohabitation relationship.

evidence.quote: A social situation has the potential to be transformed by redefining its rules.
evidence.insight: The counter-proposal is the host redefining the social situation. The information architecture must make this feel creative (the host sees the impact of their changes in real time) rather than adversarial (a rejection message).

evidence.quote: A skeptical guest who sees verified reviews, ID checks, and real host history doesn't need the platform to convince them -- another user already did. Every review is a past guest activating a future one.
evidence.insight: Inverted for hosts: a skeptical host who sees verified guest reviews, ID checks, and real stay history does not need the platform to convince them the guest is safe -- another host already did. Guest reviews in the social profile are past hosts activating the current host's confidence.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: proposal quality indicator (top of card -- instant triage signal). Secondary: terms and social profile in parallel columns (simultaneous assessment). Tertiary: counter-proposal impact preview (only when the host initiates a counter). The host triages first, assesses second, and adjusts third.
elements.disclosure_pattern: The quality indicator is always visible on the proposal card in the dashboard list view. Clicking into the proposal reveals the dual-column layout. The social profile column is fully expanded by default -- the host should not need to click to see reviews or verification. Counter-proposal tools appear only when the host clicks a 'Suggest changes' action, opening an editable version of the terms column with real-time impact calculations.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: The quality indicator is a single visual element (completeness bar or simple rating). The terms column shows maximum 5 data points (dates, duration, price, nights per week, personal message). The social profile shows maximum 4 elements (verification badge, stay count, 2-3 review excerpts, response indicator). Counter-proposal impact is shown as a single summary line per changed element.
scan_order: proposal quality indicator (top -- instant assessment)
terms summary (left column -- what they want)
social profile (right column -- who they are)
counter-proposal tools (bottom -- what can I change)
exclude: guest financial information (income, employment)
guest personal demographics beyond verification status
comparison to other pending proposals (each proposal should be evaluated on its own merits)
algorithmic compatibility scores (the host should make the social assessment, not the platform)

elements.title: Autotelic Growth Narrative: Lease-End Summary as Development Feedback
elements.problem: At lease end, the host performs what Csikszentmihalyi describes as the assessment of whether an activity increased the complexity of the self: 'A person who rarely gets bored, who does not constantly need a favorable external environment to enjoy the moment, has passed the test for having achieved a creative life' (lines 295-297). Did hosting make me more capable, more connected, more skilled at managing social complexity -- or just more tired? The platform currently provides only financial summaries at lease end (total income, payments processed). This frames hosting as a transaction, reinforcing extrinsic motivation. The information architecture fails to surface the intrinsic growth that Csikszentmihalyi identifies as the durable retention mechanism: 'There are great opportunities for joy and for growth that can only be experienced in family life, and these intrinsic rewards are no less present now' (lines 593-596). Without a growth narrative, the host's retrospective assessment defaults to 'Was the money worth the hassle?' -- a calculation that hosting often loses, since the social cost of sharing space is always tangible while the growth benefit is invisible unless explicitly surfaced.
elements.solution: Design the lease-end summary as a growth narrative, not a financial statement. The summary opens with a hosting journey timeline: 'Over 13 weeks, you hosted [Guest Name] across 13 stay cycles.' Below the timeline, three sections: (1) Financial summary (compact): total income, average per night, fee breakdown. This acknowledges the extrinsic reward without making it the centerpiece. (2) Hosting growth narrative (primary): milestones achieved ('First successful lease completed,' 'Maintained 4.8 average rating,' 'Managed 2 date changes smoothly'), skills demonstrated ('Your response time averaged under 6 hours -- faster than 75% of hosts'), and guest feedback highlights (best review quotes). This section surfaces the intrinsic rewards that are otherwise invisible. (3) Forward-looking challenges (action): 'What you could do next' with options matched to the host's demonstrated skill level -- optimize the listing, try flexible pricing, mentor a new host, explore a different guest profile. This prevents the post-lease vacuum by channeling the host's developed skill into a new challenge. The narrative should feel like a year-end review from a respected mentor, not like a platform-generated report card.

evidence.quote: A person who rarely gets bored, who does not constantly need a favorable external environment to enjoy the moment, has passed the test for having achieved a creative life.
evidence.insight: The lease-end summary helps the host answer: 'Has hosting contributed to my creative life?' By surfacing milestones, skills, and guest appreciation, the narrative makes visible the growth that might otherwise go unrecognized.

evidence.quote: Extrinsic reasons are not the only ones for staying married and for living together in families. There are great opportunities for joy and for growth that can only be experienced in family life, and these intrinsic rewards are no less present now.
evidence.insight: The growth narrative surfaces intrinsic rewards alongside the financial summary. A host who sees only income data makes the retention decision on extrinsic grounds. A host who also sees their growth, their guest's appreciation, and their developing competence has intrinsic reasons to continue.

evidence.quote: Pause preserves the work, keeps the door open, and costs nothing. Delete is a one-way door that creates regret.
evidence.insight: The forward-looking challenges section is the retention bridge between one lease and the next. A host who sees clear next steps is more likely to pause (keeping the door open) than delete (closing it permanently). The information architecture must make the path forward visible.

evidence.quote: The only way to restore flow to the relationship is by finding new challenges in it.
evidence.insight: The forward-looking challenges section is the mechanism for restoring flow after a lease ends. Without new challenges, the host faces the 'obvious challenges have been exhausted' (line 729) problem. The suggestions provide the escalation path that sustains long-term engagement.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: hosting growth narrative (intrinsic rewards -- what you gained beyond money). Secondary: financial summary (extrinsic rewards -- compact, factual). Tertiary: forward-looking challenges (retention bridge -- what comes next). The hierarchy deliberately prioritizes intrinsic over extrinsic to shift the retention calculation.
elements.disclosure_pattern: The growth narrative is the first section the host sees on the lease-end summary page -- it occupies the visual center. The financial summary appears below it in a compact, collapsible format (expandable for detail). Forward-looking challenges appear at the bottom as a set of actionable cards. The entire summary is accessible from the host's dashboard and via a notification at lease end.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: The growth narrative contains maximum 5 milestones, 2 skill indicators, and 3 guest feedback quotes. The financial summary is a single row (total income, per-night average, fee amount) with expandable detail. Forward-looking challenges show maximum 3 options. The entire summary should be readable in under 3 minutes.
scan_order: growth narrative (milestones and skill development)
guest feedback highlights (best review quotes)
financial summary (compact)
forward-looking challenges (what comes next)
exclude: comparative rankings against other hosts ('You are in the top 15%')
negative feedback without constructive framing
financial projections or income estimates for future leases (speculative and potentially misleading)
re-listing pressure or urgency ('List again before demand drops')
